Situation1: Be patient and understanding of each other's differences.
Expectation2: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation2: A serious conflict with teammates is threatening the mentee’s deliverable timeline.
Story: I sat on the edge of my bed, phone in hand, replaying the argument with my younger sister. She’d snapped at me for not listening, and I knew I should have been more patient, more understanding of her point of view. That’s what we promised each other—mutual respect, even when we disagreed. But my mind kept drifting back to the group project at work. My teammates and I were at a standstill, and the deadline was looming. My mentor had always told me to communicate challenges early, to be honest about any roadblocks. I could feel the weight of her expectations pressing on me, urging me to send that email, to ask for help before things got worse. But if I did, I’d have to admit I couldn’t manage the conflict on my own. My sister’s words echoed in my head, reminding me to be patient, to try harder to understand others. I stared at the screen, torn between reaching out to my mentor and trying, one more time, to fix things with my team. My heart pounded as I wondered which role I was about to let down.
